title: 104_hr892
content: The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 599 of title 28, United States Code, and changes the basis for preliminary investigation. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 591 of title 28, United States Code, to specify that specific information from a credible source is required for a preliminary investigation. The Attorney General must determine the need for an investigation within 15 days of receiving the information, and if there is insufficient evidence of a violation of Federal criminal law, the matter will be closed. The Attorney General must determine within 15 days if there is enough evidence of a violation of Federal criminal law based on specific information from a credible source. If there is insufficient evidence, the matter will be closed. SEC. 4. PROSECUTORIAL JURISDICTION OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. The prosecutorial jurisdiction of independent counsel is defined with specificity and limited to alleged violations of criminal law requested by the Attorney General. The independent counsel has the authority to fully investigate and prosecute these violations and related matters. The independent counsel has the authority to investigate and prosecute alleged violations of criminal law, including perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and intimidation of witnesses. Amendments specify the scope of prosecutorial jurisdiction to focus on criminal violations and related matters. SEC. 5. AUTHORITIES AND DUTIES OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. The independent counsel is authorized to investigate and prosecute criminal violations, including perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and witness intimidation. The independent counsel is entitled to office space provided by the Administrator of General Services within a Federal building. Compliance with Department of Justice policies is required, with amendments to ensure enforcement of criminal laws and release of information. Limitations on expenditures are also imposed. The amendments to section 594(f) of title 28, United States Code, made by the Independent Counsel Reauthorization Act of 1994 are repealed. A limitation on expenditures for the operation of any office of independent counsel is imposed, with funds only available for up to 2 years unless specified otherwise in an appropriations Act. SEC. 6. REMOVAL, TERMINATION, AND PERIODIC REAPPOINTMENT OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Amendments are made to the grounds for removal and termination of an independent counsel under title 28, United States Code. Failure to comply with Department of Justice policies or specific sections may lead to removal. The court division can terminate an independent counsel's office upon its own motion, the Attorney General's request, or the subject of an investigation's petition after 2 years if the investigation is completed or substantially done. The petition for removal of an independent counsel can be made after 2 years if the investigation is completed or not in the public interest. Monthly expenditures must be reported to specified committees. Periodic reappointment procedures are outlined in title 28, United States Code. The amendment regarding the effective date of reappointment procedures for independent counsel under title 28, United States Code, stipulates that after 2 years, the counsel must apply for reappointment, subject to court evaluation of their suitability for the role. The court will reappoint the applicant if deemed suitable after 2 years, otherwise appoint another qualified person. If no action is taken within 90 days, the independent counsel office will terminate. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the enactment of this Act, with recommendations to improve controls on costs of independent counsel offices under chapter 40 of title 28, United States Code.
